oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Skip Ewing Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Skip Ewing (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Skip Ewing; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Skip Ewing radio spot about his audiobiography for the Music City Album Review -- (00:06) Ewing radio spot about writing for George Strait, Kenny Rogers, and Willy Nelson; additionally, Ewing addresses releasing his own album -- (00:23) Ewing radio spot about him co-hosting with Biff Collie for the Music City Album Review -- (00:31) Ewing radio spot about previous album "Coast of Colorado" and Current album review of "The Will to Love" -- (00:46) Ewing radio spot referring to Collie as the "Biffer" and addressing the Music City Album Review -- (01:01) Ewing, thirty minute, radio spot about his audiobiography for the Music City Album Review -- (01:11) Ewing radio spot about a song he wrote for Charlie Pride and George Jones -- (01:30) Ewing, halfway point, radio spot about his audiobiography for the Music City Album Review -- (01:41) Ewing radio spot about him co-hosting with Collie -- (01:53) Ewing radio spot urging drivers to drive safe and jokes with Collie about name rights -- (02:20) Skip Ewing radio spot about his album "The Will to Love" for the Music City Album Review -- (02:33) Ewing, thirty minute remaining, radio spot about his audiobiography for the Music City Album Review -- (02:41) Ewing radio spot about his audiobiography for the Music City Album Review -- (02:49) Ewing is surprised by his role as disc jockey and he and Collie discuss Collie's tenure -- (03:26) "The Will to Love" title track is told by Ewing as a freedom of expression written with a long introduction -- (04:43) Ewing talks about Kathy Mattea and writing appreciation -- (05:35) "Please Don't Leave Me Now" is discussed by Ewing as a tale of loss he pushed on Don Schlitz -- (06:40) Ewing tells how "I'll Bring the Bottle" came to be based on a story of people talking through their troubles around a bottle -- (08:27) Collie and Ewing discuss his maturity in his young age -- (08:55) Ewing speaks on writing with Red Lane and the emotions associated from working with Lane -- (10:03) Collie introduces "If a Man Could Not Live on Love Alone" and says they shall wait for questions -- (10:15) Ewing jokes about Lane's critique of his track the first time they met -- (11:07) Ewing and Collie reflect on how Conway Twitty toured with Ewing and Conway's drive -- (13:30) Ewing speaks on his growth in understanding of artists -- (14:06) Collie radio spot introduction and Ewing reflects on writing "Karen" with Schlitz based on a real human -- (15:54) Collie inquires about Lane living in an airplane and Ewing reflects on Lane's airplane habits -- (18:11) Collie and Ewing reflect on "The Door" as a song of emotional difficulties; additionally, Ewing originally performed it for a television show -- (19:44) Ewing reflects on balance in life -- (20:20) Collie mid way radio spot -- (20:30) Ewing reflects on his belief that others should have an opportunity to record his music and writing "It Wasn't His Child" -- (22:12) Ewing talks about how "Wide Open" by Sawyer Brown increased his popularity in his own shows -- (23:10) Ewing talks about being inquired by a variety of churches -- (24:23) Collie and Ewing talk about "It's You Again" and Ewing reflects on his only time he ever writes with two others -- (26:48) Collie introduces a Hank Cochran and Willie Nelson story of Ewing's -- (27:05) Ewing tells the story of being called by Cochran to see if he wanted to meet Nelson -- (28:10) Ewing reflects on originally not being a Nelson fan and continues the story of meeting and playing music for Nelson -- (29:55) Ewing reflects on calling his father to introduce him to Nelson -- (31:25) "Age Doesn't Matter at All" is discussed as a song written on Ewing's birthday and introduces three different scenarios -- (33:32) Ewing reflects on writing "Ain't That the Way It Always Ends" with Schlitz and understanding Schlitz's direction -- (34:53) Ewing talks about all night writing sessions and people doing wrong by each other on "Ain't That the Way It Always Ends" -- (36:10) Ewing's "Ain't That the Way It Always Ends" verse break down is discussed -- (37:05) Collie and Ewing discuss Ewing's famous collaborators; George Strait is one of the artists discussed -- (38:13) Collie and Ewing joke about Ricky Van Shelton recording one of Ewing's song -- (38:36) Collie pokes about Ewing's marriage and Ewing reflects on meeting, "the rest of his life" -- (40:35) Ewing reflects on how he wants himself to come out on stage and surrounding himself with quality people -- (41:24) The final track "She's Makin' Plans" is reflected on and Ewing tells its an idea of having a child -- (42:21) Ewing and Collie talk about how people can misinterpret the song as a cheating song -- (43:30) Ewing talks about having children -- (43:47) Collie and Ewing joke and say their goodbyes --
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Ewing, Skip; Collie, Biff;
